elements.content: A series of new Zn2+-trimesate (btc3‑) metal organic frameworks (MOFs) has been isolated in the presence of various amino-alcohols under solvothermal conditions. Thus, the reaction of ZnCl2 with trimesic acid (H3btc) and the amino-alcohols triethanolamine (teoa), 2-(hydroxymethyl)piperidine (hmpip), N-tert-butyldiethanolamine (tbdeoa), 1,4-bis(2-hydroxyethyl)piperazine (bhep), N-methyldiethanolamine (mdeoa), or 4-(2-hydroxyethyl)morpholine (hem) in a 1.6:1:5.6 molar ratio in DMF afforded compounds (teoaH)2[Zn(btc)1.33] (MOAAF-1) (MOAAF = metal organic amino-alcohol framework), (NH2Me2)2(hmpipH)[Zn3(btc)3] (MOAAF-2), (NH2Me2)(tbdmaH)2[Zn3(btc)3] (MOAAF-3) (tbdma = N-tert-butyl-dimethylamine), (NH2Me2)(bhepH2)[Zn3(btc)3] (MOAAF-4), (NH2Me2)[Zn4(btc)3(mdeoa)2] (MOAAF-5), and (NH2Me2)[Zn4(btc)3(hem)2] (MOAAF-6), respectively. The compounds display 3D structures with relatively large cavities (4–10 Å) and high potential solvent-accessible areas (38–68% of the unit cell volumes). A number of novel structural features are revealed in the reported MOFs, such as unprecedented dinuclear [Zn2(COO)5]−1 secondary building units (SBUs) and unique network topologies (e.g., in compounds MOAAF-2, MOAAF-3, MOAAF-5, and MOAAF-6). The amino-alcohols employed played a key role for the appearance of such novel structural features in MOAAF 1–6 since they were found to act as bases responsible for the deprotonation of H3btc, templates, and chelating ligands. Specifically, most of the compounds synthesized were shown to be templated by protonated amino-alcohols that are involved in hydrogen bonding interactions with the frameworks, whereas in two cases (compounds MOAAF-5 and MOAAF-6) the amino-alcohols acted as chelating ligands affecting significantly the underline topology of the MOFs. The thermal stability and photoluminescence properties of the MOFs are also discussed. This work represents the initial systematic investigation on the use of combination of amino-alcohols and polycarboxylate ligands for the synthesis of new MOFs, demonstrating it as a powerful synthetic strategy for the isolation of novel MOFs.

elements.content: A series of novel Zn2+-trimesate metal organic frameworks (MOFs) have been isolated in the presence of various amino-alcohols. The reported metal organic amino-alcohol compounds display a number of unprecedented structural features, such as novel SBUs and unique network topologies. This work demonstrates a new synthetic strategy for the isolation of novel MOFs by simply combining well-known, extensively used polytopic organic ligands and amino-alcohols.
elements.clean_text: A series of novel Zn2+-trimesate metal organic frameworks (MOFs) have been isolated in the presence of various amino-alcohols. The reported metal organic amino-alcohol compounds display a number of unprecedented structural features, such as novel SBUs and unique network topologies. This work demonstrates a new synthetic strategy for the isolation of novel MOFs by simply combining well-known, extensively used polytopic organic ligands and amino-alcohols.

elements.content: The tremendous interest in metal organic frameworks (MOFs) over the past decade is due not only to their aesthetically pleasing structures and unique structural topologies but also to their potential applications in many areas including catalysis, magnetism, gas storage, sensing, etc. The key factor for the discovery of MOFs with novel structural features and potentially interesting physical properties is the development of new synthetic strategies. It is widely known that the employment of templates is a successful approach toward new porous materials. Concerning the templated synthesis of MOFs, there have been several reports on the use of various structure-directing agents such as amines, alcohols, alkali ions, polyoxometalates, metal complexes, surfactants, urea derivatives, etc. Thus, a plethora of new MOFs have been isolated with many of them showing unprecedented structural characteristics and in some cases guest-induced properties such as enhancement of porosity, electrochemical properties, catalytic activity, etc. Although a number of organic compounds have been tested as templates in the synthesis of new MOFs, amino-alcohols have received much less attention. This is rather surprising, since amino-alcohols may accomplish a variety of functions to facilitate the formation of new structures including deprotonation of the oxygen atoms of the polytopic organic ligands (e.g., carboxylic), templating effect, as well as ligation to the metal ions. In particular, these organic molecules may be highly efficient as structure-directing agents due to their excellent capability for formation of hydrogen bonds. Furthermore, they can be quite effective as ligands for the metal ions displaying a variety of coordination modes, such as terminal, chelating, or bridging ligation, resulting often in the assembly of high nuclearity metal clusters. Thus, amino-alcohols could lead to MOFs with new structural types not only due to their strong templating effect but also because they are powerful ligands that may stabilize unprecedented secondary building units (SBUs).
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The tremendous interest in metal organic frameworks (MOFs) over the past decade is due not only to their aesthetically pleasing structures and unique structural topologies but also to their potential applications in many areas including catalysis, magnetism, gas storage, sensing, etc. The key factor for the discovery of MOFs with novel structural features and potentially interesting physical properties is the development of new synthetic strategies. It is widely known that the employment of templates is a successful approach toward new porous materials. Concerning the templated synthesis of MOFs, there have been several reports on the use of various structure-directing agents such as amines, alcohols, alkali ions, polyoxometalates, metal complexes, surfactants, urea derivatives, etc. Thus, a plethora of new MOFs have been isolated with many of them showing unprecedented structural characteristics and in some cases guest-induced properties such as enhancement of porosity, electrochemical properties, catalytic activity, etc. Although a number of organic compounds have been tested as templates in the synthesis of new MOFs, amino-alcohols have received much less attention. This is rather surprising, since amino-alcohols may accomplish a variety of functions to facilitate the formation of new structures including deprotonation of the oxygen atoms of the polytopic organic ligands (e.g., carboxylic), templating effect, as well as ligation to the metal ions. In particular, these organic molecules may be highly efficient as structure-directing agents due to their excellent capability for formation of hydrogen bonds. Furthermore, they can be quite effective as ligands for the metal ions displaying a variety of coordination modes, such as terminal, chelating, or bridging ligation, resulting often in the assembly of high nuclearity metal clusters. Thus, amino-alcohols could lead to MOFs with new structural types not only due to their strong templating effect but also because they are powerful ligands that may stabilize unprecedented secondary building units (SBUs).

elements.content: Recently, we have initiated a research program that involves the use of a combination of polytopic organic ligands typically leading to polymeric structures and various amino-alcohols that can act either as structure-directing agents or ligands for the synthesis of new MOFs. Herein we present the first results of these investigations, compounds (teoaH)2[Zn(btc)1.33] (MOAAF-1) (MOAAF = metal organic amino-alcohol framework), (NH2Me2)2(hmpipH)[Zn3(btc)3] (MOAAF-2), (NH2Me2)(tbdmaH)2[Zn3(btc)3] (MOAAF-3) (tbdma= N-tert-butyl-dimethylamine), (NH2Me2)(bhepH2)[Zn3(btc)3] (MOAAF-4), (NH2Me2)[Zn4(btc)3(mdeoa)2] (MOAAF-5), and (NH2Me2)[Zn4(btc)3(hem)2] (MOAAF-6), which have been isolated by combining trimesic acid (H3btc) and triethanolamine (teoa), 2-(hydroxymethyl)piperidine (hmpip), N-tert-butyldiethanolamine (tbdeoa), 1,4-bis(2-hydroxyethyl)piperazine (bhep), N-methyldiethanolamine (mdeoa), or 4-(2-hydroxyethyl)morpholine (hem) (Scheme ). Although the structures of these new MOFs are based on the same polytopic ligand, they exhibit a remarkable diversity and unique structural–topological features that are clearly induced by the various amino-alcohols. The thermal stability and photoluminescence properties of the compounds are also reported. To the best of our knowledge, this study represents the initial systematic investigation on the use of a combination of polytopic ligands and amino – alcohols for the synthesis of novel MOFs.

elements.content:
All procedures were performed under aerobic conditions. Solvents and reagents were obtained from commercial sources and used as received.

Physical Measurements

Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed by the in-house facilities of the University of Cyprus, Chemistry Department. IR spectra were recorded on KBr pellets in the 4000–400 cm–1 range using a Shimadzu Prestige-21 spectrometer. PXRD diffraction patterns were recorded on a Shimazdu 6000 Series X-ray diffractometer (Cu Kα radiation, λ = 1.5418 Å). Photoluminescence (PL) spectra were obtained on an Edinburgh Xe900 spectrofluorometer. Thermal stability studies were performed with a Shimadzu TGA 50 thermogravimetric analyzer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

All procedures were performed under aerobic conditions. Solvents and reagents were obtained from commercial sources and used as received.

Physical Measurements

Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed by the in-house facilities of the University of Cyprus, Chemistry Department. IR spectra were recorded on KBr pellets in the 4000-400 cm-1 range using a Shimadzu Prestige-21 spectrometer. PXRD diffraction patterns were recorded on a Shimazdu 6000 Series X-ray diffractometer (Cu Kα radiation, λ = 1.5418 Å). Photoluminescence (PL) spectra were obtained on an Edinburgh Xe900 spectrofluorometer. Thermal stability studies were performed with a Shimadzu TGA 50 thermogravimetric analyzer.

elements.content: H3btc (0.30 g, 1.4 mmol) was dissolved in DMF (10 mL) in a 20 mL glass vial. Then, teoa (1.16 g, 7.8 mmol) and solid ZnCl2 (0.3 g, 2.2 mmol) were added to the reaction mixture, and the resulting solution was heated without stirring at 100 °C for 24 h. During this period, polyhedral crystals of MOAAF-1 were formed. They were isolated by filtration, washed several times with DMF and diethylether, and dried under vacuum. Yield (based on H3btc): ∼0.554 g (80%). The dried crystalline product was analyzed as MOAAF-1·H2O. Anal. Calc. for C24H38N2O15Zn: C, 43.68; H, 5.83; N, 4.24. Found: C, 43.72; H, 5.75; N, 4.35%. Selected IR data (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3376 (s), 2955 (w), 2891 (w), 1626 (s), 1583 (s), 1439 (s), 1359 (s), 1100 (s).

Syntheses

 MOAAF-1 

H3btc (0.30 g, 1.4 mmol) was dissolved in DMF (10 mL) in a 20 mL glass vial. Then, teoa (1.16 g, 7.8 mmol) and solid ZnCl2 (0.3 g, 2.2 mmol) were added to the reaction mixture, and the resulting solution was heated without stirring at 100 °C for 24 h. During this period, polyhedral crystals of MOAAF-1 were formed. They were isolated by filtration, washed several times with DMF and diethylether, and dried under vacuum. Yield (based on H3btc): ~0.554 g (80%). The dried crystalline product was analyzed as MOAAF-1⋅H2O. Anal. Calc. for C24H38N2O15Zn: C, 43.68; H, 5.83; N, 4.24. Found: C, 43.72; H, 5.75; N, 4.35%. Selected IR data (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3376 (s), 2955 (w), 2891 (w), 1626 (s), 1583 (s), 1439 (s), 1359 (s), 1100 (s).

elements.content: Compounds MOAAF-2–MOAAF-6 were synthesized with a procedure similar to that for MOAAF-1 with the exception that different amino-alcohols were used: hmpip for MOAAF-2, tbdeoa for MOAAF-3, bhep for MOAAF-4, mdeoa for MOAAF-5, and hem for MOAAF-6. The yields (based on H3btc) were 0.382 g (70%), 0.438 g (75%), 0.332 g (65%), 0.449 g (80%), and 0.417 g (75%) for MOAAF-2, MOAAF-3, MOAAF-4, MOAAF-5, and MOAAF-6, respectively. The dried crystalline product for compound MOAAF-2 was analyzed as MOAAF-2·DMF·4H2O. Anal. Calc. for C40H54N4O24Zn3: C, 41.02; H, 4.65; N, 4.78. Found: C, 41.12; H, 4.55; N, 4.68%. Selected IR data (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3412 (s), 2964 (w), 2794 (w), 1672 (s), 1595 (s), 1355 (s). The dried crystalline product for compound MOAAF-3 was analyzed as MOAAF-3·2DMF·2H2O. Anal. Calc. for C47H67N5O22Zn3: C, 45.15; H, 5.40; N, 5.60. Found: C, 45.02; H, 5.45; N, 5.68%. Selected IR data (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3452 (s), 2814 (w), 1606 (s), 1585 (s), 1357 (s). The dried crystalline product for compound MOAAF-4 was analyzed as MOAAF-4·3H2O. Anal. Calc. for C37H43N3O23Zn3: C, 40.62; H, 3.96; N, 3.84. Found: C, 40.42; H, 3.82; N, 3.95%. Selected IR data (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3444 (s), 2953 (w), 1664 (s), 1635 (s), 1358 (s). The dried crystalline product for compound MOAAF-5 was analyzed as MOAAF-5·2H2O. Anal. Calc. for C39H47N3O24Zn4: C, 38.92; H, 3.94; N, 3.49. Found: C, 39.05; H, 3.87; N, 3.55%. Selected IR data (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3448 (s), 2923 (w), 1624 (s), 1573 (s), 1442 (s), 1362 (s). The dried crystalline product for compound MOAAF-6 was analyzed as MOAAF-6 (no solvent molecules were found). Anal. Calc. for C41H43N3O22Zn4: C, 41.33; H, 3.64; N, 3.53. Found: C, 41.25; H, 3.68; N, 3.45%. Selected IR data (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3450 (s), 2923 (w), 1624 (s), 1575 (s), 1444 (s), 1364 (s). The purity of all products was also confirmed by the comparison of the experimental powder X-ray diffraction patterns to those calculated from the single crystal X-ray data (see in the Supporting Information).

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction data were collected on an Oxford-Diffraction Supernova diffractometer, equipped with a CCD area detector utilizing Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation. Suitable crystals were attached to glass fibers using paratone-N oil and transferred to a goniostat where they were cooled for data collection. Empirical absorption corrections (multiscan based on symmetry-related measurements) were applied using CrysAlis RED software. The structures were solved by direct methods using SIR2004 and refined on F 2 using full-matrix least-squares using SHELXL97. Software packages used: CrysAlis CCD for data collection, CrysAlis RED for cell refinement and data reduction, WINGX for geometric calculations, and DIAMOND for molecular graphics. The non-H atoms were treated anisotropically, whereas the H atoms were placed in calculated, ideal positions and refined as riding on their respective carbon atoms. Electron density contributions from disordered guest molecules were handled using the SQUEEZE procedure from the PLATON software suit. The solvent accessible volumes and the sizes of the cavities were calculated using the CALC SOLV and CAVITY PLOT utilities of PLATON, respectively. Topological analysis was performed with the aid of TOPOS. The structure of MOAAF-4 was refined as a nonmerohedral twin using the HKLF 5 option in SHELXL-97. CCDC 893091–893096 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif. Selected crystal data for all compounds are given in Table .

Single Crystal X-ray Crystallography

Single crystal X-ray diffraction data were collected on an Oxford-Diffraction Supernova diffractometer, equipped with a CCD area detector utilizing Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation. Suitable crystals were attached to glass fibers using paratone-N oil and transferred to a goniostat where they were cooled for data collection. Empirical absorption corrections (multiscan based on symmetry-related measurements) were applied using CrysAlis RED software. The structures were solved by direct methods using SIR2004 and refined on F 2 using full-matrix least-squares using SHELXL97. Software packages used: CrysAlis CCD for data collection, CrysAlis RED for cell refinement and data reduction, WINGX for geometric calculations, and DIAMOND for molecular graphics. The non-H atoms were treated anisotropically, whereas the H atoms were placed in calculated, ideal positions and refined as riding on their respective carbon atoms. Electron density contributions from disordered guest molecules were handled using the SQUEEZE procedure from the PLATON software suit. The solvent accessible volumes and the sizes of the cavities were calculated using the CALC SOLV and CAVITY PLOT utilities of PLATON, respectively. Topological analysis was performed with the aid of TOPOS. The structure of MOAAF-4 was refined as a nonmerohedral twin using the HKLF 5 option in SHELXL-97. CCDC 893091-893096 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif. Selected crystal data for all compounds are given in Table .

As mentioned in the introduction, our group has been investigating the use of polytopic organic ligands together with various amino-alcohols as a method for the synthesis of new MOFs. In this work, we report the initial results of these investigations that involve the employment of the well-known tricarboxylic ligand H3btc that has afforded so far a number of interesting porous MOFs in combination with amino-alcohols that can be potential templates to direct the assembly of new MOFs or ligands to build novel SBUs. Thus, reaction of ZnCl2, H3btc, and teoa in a molar ratio 1.6:1:5.6 in DMF at 100 °C resulted in compound MOAAF-1 in ∼80% yield (Scheme ). Similar reactions with the amino-alcohols hmpip, tbdeoa, bhep, mdeoa, and hem led to compounds MOAAF-2–MOAAF-6, respectively, as summarized in Scheme in 50–80% yields.

Results and Discussion

Synthesis

As mentioned in the introduction, our group has been investigating the use of polytopic organic ligands together with various amino-alcohols as a method for the synthesis of new MOFs. In this work, we report the initial results of these investigations that involve the employment of the well-known tricarboxylic ligand H3btc that has afforded so far a number of interesting porous MOFs in combination with amino-alcohols that can be potential templates to direct the assembly of new MOFs or ligands to build novel SBUs. Thus, reaction of ZnCl2, H3btc, and teoa in a molar ratio 1.6:1:5.6 in DMF at 100 °C resulted in compound MOAAF-1 in ~80% yield (Scheme ). Similar reactions with the amino-alcohols hmpip, tbdeoa, bhep, mdeoa, and hem led to compounds MOAAF-2-MOAAF-6, respectively, as summarized in Scheme  in 50-80% yields.

elements.clean_text: 2  Synthetic Routes Leading to Compounds MOAAF-1-6

elements.content: As shown in this scheme, teoa, hmpip, and bhep acted as bases and their protonated forms templated the assembly of compounds MOAAF-1, 2, and 4, respectively (see also the description of the crystal structures). Similarly, in the case of MOAAF-3 the cation of tert-butyl-dimethylammonium (tbdmaH+) that was formed in situ, possibly from the decomposition of tbdeoa, also serves as both a template and a countercation. On the other side, mdeoa and hem acted as chelating ligands for the Zn2+ ions (see also description of the crystal structures). In addition, all compounds (with the exception of MOAAF-1) contain dimethylammonium counter cations resulted from the decomposition of DMF. The purity of the products was confirmed by the similarity between the experimental and calculated (from single crystal diffraction data) PXRD patterns ( in the Supporting Information). Several reactions were performed with a variety of ZnCl2:H3btc:amino-alcohol ratios which revealed that in all cases a large excess of amino-alcohol ligands was essential in order to obtain the desired compound in high purity and decent yield. Compounds MOAAF-1–MOAAF-6 were also isolated when other Zn2+ salts (e.g., Zn(NO3)2, Zn(O2CMe)2, etc) were used in place of ZnCl2. Reactions were also performed without the presence of amino-alcohols and the product obtained in all cases was the known compound (Me2NH2)[Zn(btc)]·DMF.

elements.content: Representations of the secondary building unit (SBU)/3D structure and net topology of MOAAF-1 are shown in Figures and , respectively. Compound MOAAF-1 is a 3D coordination polymer that crystallizes in the cubic space group I4̅3d. Its repeating unit consists of one crystallographically unique Zn2+ ion coordinated in distorted tetrahedral geometry by four carboxylic oxygen atoms from four different btc3‑ ligands (Figure a), with each btc3‑ ligand connected to three Zn2+ ions. The tetrahedral [Zn(COO)4]2‑ units are interconnected through btc3‑ ligands, creating a three-dimensional framework with the ligands and Zn2+ ions representing 3- and 4-connected nodes, respectively (Figures b and ).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of MOAAF-1 

Representations of the secondary building unit (SBU)/3D structure and net topology of MOAAF-1 are shown in Figures  and , respectively. Compound MOAAF-1 is a 3D coordination polymer that crystallizes in the cubic space group I4̅3d. Its repeating unit consists of one crystallographically unique Zn2+ ion coordinated in distorted tetrahedral geometry by four carboxylic oxygen atoms from four different btc3- ligands (Figure a), with each btc3- ligand connected to three Zn2+ ions. The tetrahedral [Zn(COO)4]2- units are interconnected through btc3- ligands, creating a three-dimensional framework with the ligands and Zn2+ ions representing 3- and 4-connected nodes, respectively (Figures b and ).

elements.content: The point symbol for this net is (83)4(86)3 corresponding to the known ctn network topology (Figure ). The negative charge of the [Zn(btc)1.33]2‑ framework is balanced by teoaH+ cations filling the pores of MOAAF-1. It should be noted that teoaH+ cations were severely disordered and could not be modeled properly with the refinement of the crystal structure. However, their presence was undoubtedly confirmed by 1H NMR spectroscopic data for a sample of MOAAF-1 digested in concentrated acid ( in the Supporting Information). The solvent-accessible volume of MOAAF-1 calculated by PLATON (excluding all cations and solvents from the pores) is 5547.2 Å3, corresponding to 65.2% of the unit cell volume. The 3D structure contains cavities with diameters ∼6 Å as found by PLATON (taking into account the van der Waals radii of the atoms). A representation of the pore network of MOAAF-1 with the structure visualization program MERCURY reveals a continuous and complex 3D pore network, where the cavities communicate through wide channels with a diameter ≥4 Å ( in the Supporting Information).

elements.content: There are several MOFs with a ctn network topology, the majority of which are M3+-btc3‑ MOFs. Interestingly, one of these MOFs, compound (teoaH)3[In3(btc)4] contains teoaH+ counter cations as MOAAF-1. Other examples of polymeric species that display a ctn structural topology include a Ga3+-btc3‑ compound, a Cd2+ and a Mn2+-aminotetrazole MOFs, a Ag+-cis,cis-1,3,5-triaminocyclohexane compound, a series of lanthanide MOFs, a doubly interpenetrated Cu2+ polymer, and Be2+-containing MOF.

elements.content: Compounds MOAAF-2 and 3 display related structures (with their main difference being the type of counter cations) and thus only the structure of MOAAF-2 will be discussed in detail. Representations of the SBUs/3D structure and net topology of MOAAF-2 are shown in Figures and , respectively. MOAAF-2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P2/c. It contains two crystallographically unique Zn2+ ions coordinated by four carboxylic oxygen atoms and adopting a distorted tetrahedral geometry as well as two types of btc3‑ ligands (with stoichiometry 2:1) both exhibiting a μ4 coordination mode. Two kinds of repeating units are recognized in the structure of MOAAF-2, a mononuclear [Zn(COO)4]2‑ unit containing a distorted tetrahedral Zn2+ center and a dinuclear [Zn2(COO)5]−1 (Figure a) SBU. The latter consists of two crystallographically equivalent Zn2+ ions coordinated by three μ2- and two monodentate COO– groups and appears for the first time in MOFs chemistry. In particular, a search in the Cambridge Structural Database revealed that the [M2(COO)5] (M = any metal ion) unit present in MOAAF-2 is quite uncommon presented only in the (H2NMe2)[Zn2(O2CNMe2)5]·MeCN compound that is a discrete dinuclear complex and in a Co17 metal cluster.

Crystal Structures of MOAAF-2 and 3 

Compounds MOAAF-2 and 3 display related structures (with their main difference being the type of counter cations) and thus only the structure of MOAAF-2 will be discussed in detail. Representations of the SBUs/3D structure and net topology of MOAAF-2 are shown in Figures  and , respectively. MOAAF-2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P2/c. It contains two crystallographically unique Zn2+ ions coordinated by four carboxylic oxygen atoms and adopting a distorted tetrahedral geometry as well as two types of btc3- ligands (with stoichiometry 2:1) both exhibiting a μ4 coordination mode. Two kinds of repeating units are recognized in the structure of MOAAF-2, a mononuclear [Zn(COO)4]2- unit containing a distorted tetrahedral Zn2+ center and a dinuclear [Zn2(COO)5]-1 (Figure a) SBU. The latter consists of two crystallographically equivalent Zn2+ ions coordinated by three μ2- and two monodentate COO- groups and appears for the first time in MOFs chemistry. In particular, a search in the Cambridge Structural Database revealed that the [M2(COO)5] (M = any metal ion) unit present in MOAAF-2 is quite uncommon presented only in the (H2NMe2)[Zn2(O2CNMe2)5]⋅MeCN compound that is a discrete dinuclear complex and in a Co17 metal cluster.

elements.content: The 3D structure contains two types of cavities; the first one displays a hexagonal shape and relatively large diameters ∼9–10 Å and the second one rhombic shape and smaller diameters ∼4–5 Å as found by PLATON (taking into account the van der Waals radii of the atoms), Figure c. The pores accommodate protonated hmpipH+ ions (positionally disordered over two positions) that are involved in hydrogen bonding interactions (2.6–2.7 Å) via their N and OH groups with carboxylic oxygen atoms of the btc3‑ ligands (Figure b) as well as [NH2Me2]+ cations and lattice solvents.

The pores accommodate protonated hmpipH+ ions (positionally disordered over two positions) that are involved in hydrogen bonding interactions (2.6-2.7 Å) via their N and OH groups with carboxylic oxygen atoms of the btc3- ligands (Figure b) as well as [NH2Me2]+ cations and lattice solvents.

elements.content: The solvent-accessible volume of MOAAF-2 calculated by PLATON (after refining the structure excluding all cations and solvents from the pores) is 2387 Å3, corresponding to 67.8% of the unit cell volume. The pore network of MOAAF-2 is continuous, and the cavities are connected through wide channels with a diameter of ≥4 Å as found with MERCURY ( in the Supporting Information).

elements.content: As mentioned above, compounds MOAAF-2 and -3 exhibit similar structures. Their main differences lie in the crystal systems and space groups in which these compounds crystallize (monoclinic P2/c for MOAAF-2 and orthorhombic Cmma for MOAAF-3) and the type of counter cations (hmpipH+ /[NH2Me2]+ for MOAAF-2 and tbdmaH+/[NH2Me2]+ for MOAAF-3) located in their pores. Interestingly, tbdmaH+ which was not used in the reaction mixture that resulted in MOAAF-3 and formed in situ possibly from the decomposition of tbdeoa, appears for the first time in a crystal structure ( in the Supporting Information), as revealed by a search in the Cambridge Structural Database.

elements.content: Representations of the SBUs/3D structure and net topology of MOAAF-4 are shown in Figures and , respectively. Compound MOAAF-4 crystallizes in the trigonal space group R3̅. Its asymmetric unit contains three crystallographically unique Zn2+ centers, three independent btc3‑ ligands, one bhepH2 2+, one [NH2Me2]+, and four DMF lattice molecules. There are two types of repeating units in the structure, a mononuclear [Zn(COO)4]2‑ one containing a tetrahedral Zn2+ ion linked to four Ocarboxylate atoms coming from four different btc3‑ ligands and a dinuclear [Zn2(COO)5]−1 SBU (Figure a). The [Zn2(COO)5]−1 SBU is asymmetric since one of its Zn2+ ions is ligated to three μ2- and one monodentate COO– groups adopting a distorted tetrahedral geometry, whereas the second one is coordinated to three μ2- and one chelating COO– groups adopting a distorted trigonal bipyramidal geometry. The main difference between the dinuclear SBUs of MOAAF-4 and those in MOAAF-2 and -3 compounds lies in the fact that the SBUs in the latter MOFs are symmetric containing two Zn2+ ions that adopt a distorted tetrahedral geometry (see above).

Crystal Structure of MOAAF-4 

Representations of the SBUs/3D structure and net topology of MOAAF-4 are shown in Figures  and , respectively. Compound MOAAF-4 crystallizes in the trigonal space group R3̅. Its asymmetric unit contains three crystallographically unique Zn2+ centers, three independent btc3- ligands, one bhepH2 2+, one [NH2Me2]+, and four DMF lattice molecules. There are two types of repeating units in the structure, a mononuclear [Zn(COO)4]2- one containing a tetrahedral Zn2+ ion linked to four Ocarboxylate atoms coming from four different btc3- ligands and a dinuclear [Zn2(COO)5]-1 SBU (Figure a). The [Zn2(COO)5]-1 SBU is asymmetric since one of its Zn2+ ions is ligated to three μ2- and one monodentate COO- groups adopting a distorted tetrahedral geometry, whereas the second one is coordinated to three μ2- and one chelating COO- groups adopting a distorted trigonal bipyramidal geometry. The main difference between the dinuclear SBUs of MOAAF-4 and those in MOAAF-2 and -3 compounds lies in the fact that the SBUs in the latter MOFs are symmetric containing two Zn2+ ions that adopt a distorted tetrahedral geometry (see above).

elements.content: The 3D structure contains large wheel-shaped and hexagonal cavities with diameters ∼7–10 Å as found by PLATON (taking into account the van der Waals radii of the atoms), Figure c. The hexagonal pores accommodate deprotonated bhepH2 2+ ions (Figure b) that are involved in hydrogen bonding interactions (2.7 Å) via their OH groups with carboxylic oxygen atoms of the btc3‑ ligands and via their N atoms with O atoms of DMF guest molecules also hosted in these pores. The wheel-shaped cavities contain [NH2Me2]+ cations and DMF guest molecules which are also involved in hydrogen bonding interactions (the N atom of [NH2Me2]+ cation is hydrogen bonded to the O atoms of a DMF and a btc3‑ molecules).

elements.content: Compounds MOAAF-5 and -6 display related structures (with the exception of the type of the amino-alcohol ligand) and thus, only the structure of MOAAF-5 will be discussed in detail. Representations of the SBUs/3D structure and net topology of MOAAF-5 are shown in Figures and , respectively. MOAAF-5 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group I2/a with its asymmetric unit consisting of two crystallographically unique Zn2+ centers, two types of btc3‑ ligands (with stoichiometry 2:1), one mdeoa ligand, as well as disordered [NH2Me2]+ cations and solvent molecules. The structure is based on two types of repeating units, a mononuclear [Zn(COO)2(mdeoa)] and a dinuclear [Zn2(COO)5]−1 units. The Zn2+ ion of the mononuclear unit is coordinated by one chelating and one monodentate COO– groups and a tridentate mdeoa ligand (i.e., connected via its amine and two hydroxyl groups), adopting an octahedral coordination geometry (Figure a) whereas the dinuclear SBU is very similar to those appeared in MOAAF-2 and -3, described in a previous paragraph.

Crystal Structures of MOAAF-5 and -6 

Compounds MOAAF-5 and -6 display related structures (with the exception of the type of the amino-alcohol ligand) and thus, only the structure of MOAAF-5 will be discussed in detail. Representations of the SBUs/3D structure and net topology of MOAAF-5 are shown in Figures  and , respectively. MOAAF-5 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group I2/a with its asymmetric unit consisting of two crystallographically unique Zn2+ centers, two types of btc3- ligands (with stoichiometry 2:1), one mdeoa ligand, as well as disordered [NH2Me2]+ cations and solvent molecules. The structure is based on two types of repeating units, a mononuclear [Zn(COO)2(mdeoa)] and a dinuclear [Zn2(COO)5]-1 units. The Zn2+ ion of the mononuclear unit is coordinated by one chelating and one monodentate COO- groups and a tridentate mdeoa ligand (i.e., connected via its amine and two hydroxyl groups), adopting an octahedral coordination geometry (Figure a) whereas the dinuclear SBU is very similar to those appeared in MOAAF-2 and -3, described in a previous paragraph.

The [Zn(COO)2(mdeoa)] units simply bridge between the two types of btc3‑ ligands and therefore, are topologically silent. The point symbol for this net is (4.6.8)2(42.62.84.102)(62.8) and represents a unique topology. The solvent-accessible volume of MOAAF-5 calculated by PLATON (excluding all cations and solvents from the pores) is 2211 Å3, corresponding to 37.8% of the unit cell volume.

elements.content: The representation of the voids of MOAAF-5 with MERCURY revealed that the pores are connected through narrow passages that are ∼3.2 Å wide ( in the Supporting Information). The structure of MOAAF-6 is very similar to that of MOAAF-5, as mentioned above. The main differences between them are (a) the type of the amino-alcohol ligand being mdeoa for MOAAF-5 and hem for MOAAF-6 and (b) the coordination geometry adopted by the Zn2+ ions connected with the amino-alcohol, which is octahedral [Zn(COO)2(mdeoa)] in the structure of MOAAF-5 and square-pyramidal [Zn(COO)2(hem)] (with three carboxylate and one OH groups in the equatorial plane and one axial amine ligand) in the structure of MOAAF-6 ( in the Supporting Information). Finally, in both compounds the amino-alcohols (mdeoa and hem) are neutral, a fact that is supported by the charge balance requirements, the inspection of bond distances and bond valence sum (BVS) calculations for the coordinated O atoms of the amino-alcohols indicating BVS values of 1.2–1.3 typical of OH groups.
elements.clean_text: The representation of the voids of MOAAF-5 with MERCURY revealed that the pores are connected through narrow passages that are ~3.2 Å wide ( in the Supporting Information). The structure of MOAAF-6 is very similar to that of MOAAF-5, as mentioned above. The main differences between them are (a) the type of the amino-alcohol ligand being mdeoa for MOAAF-5 and hem for MOAAF-6 and (b) the coordination geometry adopted by the Zn2+ ions connected with the amino-alcohol, which is octahedral [Zn(COO)2(mdeoa)] in the structure of MOAAF-5 and square-pyramidal [Zn(COO)2(hem)] (with three carboxylate and one OH groups in the equatorial plane and one axial amine ligand) in the structure of MOAAF-6 ( in the Supporting Information). Finally, in both compounds the amino-alcohols (mdeoa and hem) are neutral, a fact that is supported by the charge balance requirements, the inspection of bond distances and bond valence sum (BVS) calculations for the coordinated O atoms of the amino-alcohols indicating BVS values of 1.2-1.3 typical of OH groups.

elements.content: At this point, it is worthy comparing the structures of MOAAF-1–MOAAF-6 with those of other Zn-btc MOFs reported in the literature. A Cambridge database search revealed that there are 31 Zn-btc MOFs containing the tricarboxylic ligand as the only type of bridging ligand.
elements.clean_text:
Comparison of MOAAF-1 - MOAAF-6 with Reported Zn-btc MOFs

At this point, it is worthy comparing the structures of MOAAF-1-MOAAF-6 with those of other Zn-btc MOFs reported in the literature. A Cambridge database search revealed that there are 31 Zn-btc MOFs containing the tricarboxylic ligand as the only type of bridging ligand.

elements.content: Selected structural data for all Zn-btc MOFs are provided in Table . This comparison revealed that all coordination modes for btc3‑ found in MOAAF-1–MOAAF-6, shown in Scheme (MOAAF-1, B; MOAAF-2 and 3, A; MOAAF-4, A and D; MOAAF-5, A and C; MOAAF-6, A and D;) have been already appeared in Zn-btc MOFs. In particular, the coordination modes A, B, and D shown in Scheme have been frequently observed, whereas mode C has been appeared in only one other example.

elements.clean_text: 3  Coordination Modes of btc3- in Compounds MOAAF-1-MOAAF-6

elements.content: Comparing the topological features of compounds MOAAF-1–MOAAF-6 with those of known Zn-btc MOFs (Table ), it was realized that MOAAF-1 is the only Zn-btc MOF with a ctn network topology and, more importantly, compounds MOAAF-2–MOAAF-6 display 3- or 4-nodal nets and rare or unprecedented structural topologies, whereas the reported Zn-btc compounds with 3D structures show binodal (3,4, 3,5, or 3,6)-nets with only one exception being compound [NH2Me2]+[Zn3(btc)3]·4DMA which displays similar topology to that of MOAAF-4 (see above). It is remarkable that MOAAF-1–MOAAF-6 exhibit new topological characteristics compared to known Zn-btc MOFs, taking into account that the observed btc3‑ connectivity modes in MOAAF-1–MOAAF-6 have been reported for several Zn-btc compounds. The novel topological features of MOAAF-1–MOAAF-6 have probably resulted from the presence of unprecedented or rare SBUs (dinuclear units in compounds MOAAF-2–MOAAF-4) in combination with the templating effect (compounds MOAAF-1–MOAAF-4) and ligation (compounds MOAAF-5 and -6) of the amino-alcohols.
elements.clean_text: Comparing the topological features of compounds MOAAF-1-MOAAF-6 with those of known Zn-btc MOFs (Table ), it was realized that MOAAF-1 is the only Zn-btc MOF with a ctn network topology and, more importantly, compounds MOAAF-2-MOAAF-6 display 3- or 4-nodal nets and rare or unprecedented structural topologies, whereas the reported Zn-btc compounds with 3D structures show binodal (3,4, 3,5, or 3,6)-nets with only one exception being compound [NH2Me2]+[Zn3(btc)3]⋅4DMA which displays similar topology to that of MOAAF-4 (see above). It is remarkable that MOAAF-1-MOAAF-6 exhibit new topological characteristics compared to known Zn-btc MOFs, taking into account that the observed btc3- connectivity modes in MOAAF-1-MOAAF-6 have been reported for several Zn-btc compounds. The novel topological features of MOAAF-1-MOAAF-6 have probably resulted from the presence of unprecedented or rare SBUs (dinuclear units in compounds MOAAF-2-MOAAF-4) in combination with the templating effect (compounds MOAAF-1-MOAAF-4) and ligation (compounds MOAAF-5 and -6) of the amino-alcohols.

elements.content: The thermal stability of MOAAF-1–MOAAF-6 was investigated by means of the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) technique. The TG/DTG (1st derivative) data for compounds MOAAF-1–MOAAF-5 show weight losses from 20 °C to temperatures 100–200 °C assigned to the removal of lattice solvents (H2O or/and DMF), whereas MOAAF-6 displays no losses at this temperature range ( in the Supporting Information). At higher temperatures, all compounds exhibit a series of weight losses attributed to the elimination of organic cations, amino-alcohols, and btc3‑ ligands. The decomposition of the compounds is completed at temperatures in between 600 and 830 °C. A detailed description of the thermal analyses data for MOAAF-1 - MOAAF-6 and the TG/DTG diagrams () are provided in the .
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Stability Studies

The thermal stability of MOAAF-1-MOAAF-6 was investigated by means of the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) technique. The TG/DTG (1st derivative) data for compounds MOAAF-1-MOAAF-5 show weight losses from 20 °C to temperatures 100-200 °C assigned to the removal of lattice solvents (H2O or/and DMF), whereas MOAAF-6 displays no losses at this temperature range ( in the Supporting Information). At higher temperatures, all compounds exhibit a series of weight losses attributed to the elimination of organic cations, amino-alcohols, and btc3- ligands. The decomposition of the compounds is completed at temperatures in between 600 and 830 °C. A detailed description of the thermal analyses data for MOAAF-1 - MOAAF-6 and the TG/DTG diagrams () are provided in the .

elements.content: The PL properties of compounds MOAAF-1–MOAAF-6 were investigated at room temperature. The H3btc ligand exhibits a strong emission at ∼380 nm when excited at 343 nm that is attributed to a π* → n transition, whereas the amino-alcohols (teoa, hmpip, tbdeoa, mdeoa, hem, and bhep) showed no PL emissions. Compounds MOAAF-2 and -5 display emission peaks at 405 (exc. 340 nm) and 430 nm (exc. 360 nm), respectively (Figure ). Thus, the emission wavelengths of MOAAF-2 and -5 are significantly red-shifted compared to that of free H3btc ligand, and this is probably caused by a ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). On the other side, MOAAF-1, -3, -4, and -6 show very weak emissions when excited at ∼340 nm. The inconsistency in the emissions of MOAAF-1–MOAAF-6 is probably due to their differences in the coordination environment of Zn2+ ions and/or their different counter cations and lattice solvents.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescence (PL) Studies

The PL properties of compounds MOAAF-1-MOAAF-6 were investigated at room temperature. The H3btc ligand exhibits a strong emission at ~380 nm when excited at 343 nm that is attributed to a π* → n transition, whereas the amino-alcohols (teoa, hmpip, tbdeoa, mdeoa, hem, and bhep) showed no PL emissions. Compounds MOAAF-2 and -5 display emission peaks at 405 (exc. 340 nm) and 430 nm (exc. 360 nm), respectively (Figure ). Thus, the emission wavelengths of MOAAF-2 and -5 are significantly red-shifted compared to that of free H3btc ligand, and this is probably caused by a ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). On the other side, MOAAF-1, -3, -4, and -6 show very weak emissions when excited at ~340 nm. The inconsistency in the emissions of MOAAF-1-MOAAF-6 is probably due to their differences in the coordination environment of Zn2+ ions and/or their different counter cations and lattice solvents.

elements.content: In conclusion, a series of new Zn2+ MOFs (MOAAF-1–MOAAF-6) have been isolated from reactions that involved use of a combination of H3btc with the amino-alcohols teoa, hmpip, tbdeoa, mdeoa, hem, and bhep. All compounds showed 3D structures with relatively large pores (4–10 Å) and solvent-accessible volumes (38–68% of the unit cell volumes) and displayed a number of unprecedented structural features, such as novel SBUs and unique network topologies. Taking into account that over 30 Zn-btc MOFs and numerous other 3d metal-btc compounds are known and almost all possible connectivity modes of btc3‑ have been already reported, it is remarkable that four of the six MOFs presented in this work exhibit novel network topologies. Clearly, amino-alcohols played a key role in the isolation of MOFs with novel structural characteristics as were shown to act with various different ways, e.g. as bases (teoa, hmpip, bhep), templates (teoa, hmpip, bhep), or chelating ligands (mdeoa, hem). This study represents the initial systematic investigation on the use of a combination of a polytopic ligand and an aminoalcohol for the isolation of MOFs and demonstrates it as an efficient synthetic method for the isolation of novel MOFs, even when well-known polytopic ligands are employed. In addition, it provides insights on the sensitivity of the synthesis of MOFs not only to reaction conditions but also to the additives present in the reaction solution. Given the plethora of polytopic ligands and amino-alcohols, a large number of MOFs with new structural features and potentially interesting physical properties may be obtained by their proper combination. By applying this synthetic method, we have already prepared a large number of new MOFs that will be reported in future papers.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, a series of new Zn2+ MOFs (MOAAF-1-MOAAF-6) have been isolated from reactions that involved use of a combination of H3btc with the amino-alcohols teoa, hmpip, tbdeoa, mdeoa, hem, and bhep. All compounds showed 3D structures with relatively large pores (4-10 Å) and solvent-accessible volumes (38-68% of the unit cell volumes) and displayed a number of unprecedented structural features, such as novel SBUs and unique network topologies. Taking into account that over 30 Zn-btc MOFs and numerous other 3d metal-btc compounds are known and almost all possible connectivity modes of btc3- have been already reported, it is remarkable that four of the six MOFs presented in this work exhibit novel network topologies. Clearly, amino-alcohols played a key role in the isolation of MOFs with novel structural characteristics as were shown to act with various different ways, e.g. as bases (teoa, hmpip, bhep), templates (teoa, hmpip, bhep), or chelating ligands (mdeoa, hem). This study represents the initial systematic investigation on the use of a combination of a polytopic ligand and an aminoalcohol for the isolation of MOFs and demonstrates it as an efficient synthetic method for the isolation of novel MOFs, even when well-known polytopic ligands are employed. In addition, it provides insights on the sensitivity of  the synthesis of MOFs not only to reaction conditions but also to the additives present in the reaction solution. Given the plethora of polytopic ligands and amino-alcohols, a large number of MOFs with new structural features and potentially interesting physical properties may be obtained by their proper combination. By applying this synthetic method, we have already prepared a large number of new MOFs that will be reported in future papers.

cln_elements.content:
H3btc (0.30 g, 1.4 mmol) was dissolved in DMF (10 mL) in a 20 mL glass vial. Then, teoa (1.16 g, 7.8 mmol) and solid ZnCl2 (0.3 g, 2.2 mmol) were added to the reaction mixture, and the resulting solution was heated without stirring at 100 °C for 24 h. During this period, polyhedral crystals of MOAAF-1 were formed. They were isolated by filtration, washed several times with DMF and diethylether, and dried under vacuum. Yield (based on H3btc): ∼0.554 g (80%). The dried crystalline product was analyzed as MOAAF-1·H2O. Anal. Calc. for C24H38N2O15Zn: C, 43.68; H, 5.83; N, 4.24. Found: C, 43.72; H, 5.75; N, 4.35%. Selected IR data (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3376 (s), 2955 (w), 2891 (w), 1626 (s), 1583 (s), 1439 (s), 1359 (s), 1100 (s).

<bold>MOAAF-2–MOAAF-6</bold>

Compounds MOAAF-2–MOAAF-6 were synthesized with a procedure similar to that for MOAAF-1 with the exception that different amino-alcohols were used: hmpip for MOAAF-2, tbdeoa for MOAAF-3, bhep for MOAAF-4, mdeoa for MOAAF-5, and hem for MOAAF-6. The yields (based on H3btc) were 0.382 g (70%), 0.438 g (75%), 0.332 g (65%), 0.449 g (80%), and 0.417 g (75%) for MOAAF-2, MOAAF-3, MOAAF-4, MOAAF-5, and MOAAF-6, respectively. The dried crystalline product for compound MOAAF-2 was analyzed as MOAAF-2·DMF·4H2O. Anal. Calc. for C40H54N4O24Zn3: C, 41.02; H, 4.65; N, 4.78. Found: C, 41.12; H, 4.55; N, 4.68%. Selected IR data (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3412 (s), 2964 (w), 2794 (w), 1672 (s), 1595 (s), 1355 (s). The dried crystalline product for compound MOAAF-3 was analyzed as MOAAF-3·2DMF·2H2O. Anal. Calc. for C47H67N5O22Zn3: C, 45.15; H, 5.40; N, 5.60. Found: C, 45.02; H, 5.45; N, 5.68%. Selected IR data (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3452 (s), 2814 (w), 1606 (s), 1585 (s), 1357 (s). The dried crystalline product for compound MOAAF-4 was analyzed as MOAAF-4·3H2O. Anal. Calc. for C37H43N3O23Zn3: C, 40.62; H, 3.96; N, 3.84. Found: C, 40.42; H, 3.82; N, 3.95%. Selected IR data (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3444 (s), 2953 (w), 1664 (s), 1635 (s), 1358 (s). The dried crystalline product for compound MOAAF-5 was analyzed as MOAAF-5·2H2O. Anal. Calc. for C39H47N3O24Zn4: C, 38.92; H, 3.94; N, 3.49. Found: C, 39.05; H, 3.87; N, 3.55%. Selected IR data (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3448 (s), 2923 (w), 1624 (s), 1573 (s), 1442 (s), 1362 (s). The dried crystalline product for compound MOAAF-6 was analyzed as MOAAF-6 (no solvent molecules were found). Anal. Calc. for C41H43N3O22Zn4: C, 41.33; H, 3.64; N, 3.53. Found: C, 41.25; H, 3.68; N, 3.45%. Selected IR data (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3450 (s), 2923 (w), 1624 (s), 1575 (s), 1444 (s), 1364 (s). The purity of all products was also confirmed by the comparison of the experimental powder X-ray diffraction patterns to those calculated from the single crystal X-ray data (see in the Supporting Information).

Results and DiscussionSynthesis

As mentioned in the introduction, our group has been investigating the use of polytopic organic ligands together with various amino-alcohols as a method for the synthesis of new MOFs. In this work, we report the initial results of these investigations that involve the employment of the well-known tricarboxylic ligand H3btc that has afforded so far a number of interesting porous MOFs in combination with amino-alcohols that can be potential templates to direct the assembly of new MOFs or ligands to build novel SBUs. Thus, reaction of ZnCl2, H3btc, and teoa in a molar ratio 1.6:1:5.6 in DMF at 100 °C resulted in compound MOAAF-1 in ∼80% yield (Scheme ). Similar reactions with the amino-alcohols hmpip, tbdeoa, bhep, mdeoa, and hem led to compounds MOAAF-2–MOAAF-6, respectively, as summarized in Scheme in 50–80% yields.

cln_elements.content:
The point symbol for this net is (83)4(86)3 corresponding to the known ctn network topology (Figure ). The negative charge of the [Zn(btc)1.33]2‑ framework is balanced by teoaH+ cations filling the pores of MOAAF-1. It should be noted that teoaH+ cations were severely disordered and could not be modeled properly with the refinement of the crystal structure. However, their presence was undoubtedly confirmed by 1H NMR spectroscopic data for a sample of MOAAF-1 digested in concentrated acid ( in the Supporting Information). The solvent-accessible volume of MOAAF-1 calculated by PLATON (excluding all cations and solvents from the pores) is 5547.2 Å3, corresponding to 65.2% of the unit cell volume. The 3D structure contains cavities with diameters ∼6 Å as found by PLATON (taking into account the van der Waals radii of the atoms). A representation of the pore network of MOAAF-1 with the structure visualization program MERCURY reveals a continuous and complex 3D pore network, where the cavities communicate through wide channels with a diameter ≥4 Å ( in the Supporting Information).

The solvent-accessible volume of MOAAF-2 calculated by PLATON (after refining the structure excluding all cations and solvents from the pores) is 2387 Å3, corresponding to 67.8% of the unit cell volume. The pore network of MOAAF-2 is continuous, and the cavities are connected through wide channels with a diameter of ≥4 Å as found with MERCURY ( in the Supporting Information).

The solvent-accessible volume of MOAAF-4 calculated by PLATON (excluding all cations and solvents from the pores) is 18211.5 Å3 corresponding to 63.7% of the unit cell volume. The representation of the voids of MOAAF-4 with MERCURY revealed a continuous pore network, in which the cavities are connected through wide channels with a diameter ≥4 Å ( in the Supporting Information).

Thermal Stability Studies

The thermal stability of MOAAF-1–MOAAF-6 was investigated by means of the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) technique. The TG/DTG (1st derivative) data for compounds MOAAF-1–MOAAF-5 show weight losses from 20 °C to temperatures 100–200 °C assigned to the removal of lattice solvents (H2O or/and DMF), whereas MOAAF-6 displays no losses at this temperature range ( in the Supporting Information). At higher temperatures, all compounds exhibit a series of weight losses attributed to the elimination of organic cations, amino-alcohols, and btc3‑ ligands. The decomposition of the compounds is completed at temperatures in between 600 and 830 °C. A detailed description of the thermal analyses data for MOAAF-1 - MOAAF-6 and the TG/DTG diagrams () are provided in the .
